triples.evidence: Solid-state drives (SSDs) with tens of NAND flash chips and highly parallel architectures are widely used in enterprise and client storage systems.
Solid-state drives (SSDs) with tens of NAND flash chips and highly parallel architectures are widely used in enterprise and client storage systems.

Our steady-state experiments indicate that midrange/high-end SSDs with dynamic allocation can provide I/O operations per second (IOPS) improvement of up to 3.3x/9.6x, response time improvement of up to 56%/32%, and about 88%/96% average reduction in the standard deviation of erase counts of NAND flash blocks.

Our steady-state experiments indicate that midrange/high-end SSDs with dynamic allocation can provide I/O operations per second (IOPS) improvement of up to 3.3x/9.6x, response time improvement of up to 56%/32%, and about 88%/96% average reduction in the standard deviation of erase counts of NAND flash blocks.
Our steady-state experiments indicate that midrange/high-end SSDs with dynamic allocation can provide I/O operations per second (IOPS) improvement of up to 3.3x/9.6x.

Our steady-state experiments indicate that midrange/high-end SSDs with dynamic allocation can provide I/O operations per second (IOPS) improvement of up to 3.3x/9.6x, response time improvement of up to 56%/32%.
We show that dynamism helps to mitigate performance and endurance overheads of garbage collection.
